pros: You get to self schedule as long as you put yourself to work at least 4 weekend days in a 6 week period. cons: Even if management is aware of an employee(s) that do below the bare minimum they will not fire them, even if multiple employees alert management. You will just keep hearing, "we are working to resolve this issue, that employee is under review" The bonuses are not competitive. Pay is based on a tier system that also takes into account time with the company. Therefore you can be reviewed by management as one of the best employees on the unit but make less than one of the worst if that person worked longer than you and meets more of the tier criteria. I work on their "observation-medsurg" unit and often get floated to other units that are unable to retain staff- especially telemetry. DO NOT work tele unless you want to risk your license with unsafe patient-nurse ratios. Ratio usually 5 or 6 to 1, my unit often was the first to go 6-1 with supervisor taking patients. Short staffed hospital wide

review_title: Exceptional Role with exceptional management and staff!
job_title: Respiratory Equipment Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Too many pro's to list but I'll try to summarize it the best I can.

This role is new to Honorhealth and to the Respiratory department. So far, with full transparency, I can safely say that I enjoy my time with this hospital and with the Respiratory department.

The management team is some of the nicest, best people I've worked with thus far in the medical field. They are keen to answering your questions, providing advice/tips and helping you throughout your shift with whatever may come up. They're approachable and want you to succeed. Nothing but 5 stars out of 5. 

This is something you just don't see anymore, which is a shame, so this is very meaningful to me and I appreciate it everyday.

THEY WANT YOU TO SUCCEED!

The role itself is unique but you are able to develop your own style on how you approach things, as long as the tasks are done from a day-to-day basis. It's quite interesting to me because prior to starting this role, I knew very little about Respiratory in general but was willing to learn and understand the different concepts.

It is a mixture of things from maintaining the Respiratory equipment/devices to keeping areas stocked and ready to go to making the department run a little more efficiently when it comes to the tasks of the R.E.T.

All in all, I would recommend this position. The team just makes everything better in so many ways!

A+
cons: No cons to share, it really is that great.

pros: The patients are kind. There is a lot of knowledgeable staff and physicians.
cons:
This place considers its nurses and staff to be disposable and treats them like crap. They have claimed they can’t give raises this year with covid, but are offering travel assignments for nurses at +$100/hour. They won’t give hazard pay for covid and make you reuse PPE with an unproven “disinfection process” for N95s. If you get covid at work, which you likely will because you’re only given a 1 layer paper mask, they will claim you got it in the community and refuse to pay sick time. Their “compromise” was to allow employees to go negative on sick time and PPO, essentially making you pay it back. This lasted all of a few months, and they decided it was again too costly. If you get covid, they send you back to work after 10 days and won’t reswab you. 

This organization claims to care about their employees and community, but really they just care about making the few leaders at the too more wealthy and allowing nurses to suffer and burn out and get sick on the job. They’ve even received state and federal funds and refuse to help their own employees with it. Now they are promoting that they will give employees the vaccine in the next few weeks even without it being fully tested and giving employees the option or asking for feedback.

review_title: Very satisfied with Honor Health for years
pros:
Ample opportunity for growth, Honor Health believes in nurturing, coaching, and promoting from within. They do not restrict jobs to internal staff only. I believe bringing in outside employment is good for a company as it brings new and fresh ideas. The company does not get stuck with a mentally of their way or no way.

It is highly encouraged that staff provide their ideas. After working for a few hospitals where ideas were greeted with hostility from management, it was refreshing to find a place that wants to hear employee ideas.

Employee discounts, great PTO, great tuition assistance compared to other hospitals and corporations.

HR is a department that takes complaints seriously and I've had results when I've gone to them with grievances. Something I've never found at any other hospital in the valley.

I've had truly horrible and disgusting managers so I can spot a terrible one a mile away. I've dealt with it all from managers, harassment, discrimination, sexual advances, put downs, mental and emotional abuse. But I've never had a single issue in all my years of honor health. They truly train and groom their management team to succeed and to push the team to succeed.
cons: Low pay. Best hospital ever but compared to other hospitals the pay is low and unfair. Employees with less experience, college education and such, make more then my pay which I had to fight for and complain to HR about for a year before I was brought up to a slightly more acceptable level that was still below newbies without experience.

review_title: Management at Corporate Office has developed a culture of fear
job_title: Support Services Professional in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Beautiful building and location, covered parking, lots of hard working and good people
cons: New management was  brought into the corporate office in the past couple years and ever since, there has been a tremendous amount of employee turnover and a prevailing culture of fear.  The organization itself is operating in a multimillion dollar deficit, so they are using that as an excuse to "eliminate positions."  Yet then management continues to receive raises and bonuses as loyal employees are let go.  It's a very hard pill to swallow as you walk through the employee parking garage past luxury car after luxury car.  Coming here every day is like torture, because you never know if today is the day you'll lose your job.  Management is firing people who work hard and have the most knowledge about the company and the systems.  Management acts transparent, but are dishonest with answers.  Very hostile, passive aggressive environment.  There is little to no communication, and the right hand has no idea what the left is doing.

review_title: No Merit Raises--  Incentive  $$ to new hires
job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Great people to work with, co-workers are very supportive of each other.
cons: No merit raises to staff that have worked for Honor Health and thru covid-19. However, a lot of new hire positions posted with incentive money of up to 10K to new hires. Does not take care of the staff that has taken care of the patients during the pandemic. Any year that you are told "no raises" it is not a good year, however in the middle of a pandemic when you are asking the staff to work harder and longer with no support, risking their health and safety- it really shows Honor Health's lack of value for their staff. Staff that has worked thru low-workloads, floating to other units and short staffing deserve to be recognized for their efforts. Instead of bonues to people that have never worked for your hospital you should acknowledge the people that have worked to keep the hospital doors open and caring for the patients in your community.

job_title: Prefer Not To Say in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Company is great, benefits great.
cons: Company is focused on dollars brought in and strict on dollars spent on company expenditures (cutbacks/layoffs).  Leadership focused on money brought in, some are people-centric however most are not. They preach trust culture, employee engagement however a lot of employee's (especially my immediate co-workers) fear for their jobs when they make mistakes.  They preach that leadership are approachable but it only leaves employees with doubt as some leadership equate mistakes with lack of knowing your duties. Constructive criticism is lacking in certain departments while destructive criticism is for certain departments. I've had co-workers go to HR with their concerns, but they didn't feel assured and a week later my co-worker resigned after speaking to her leadership.

pros: Generous PTO, somewhat flexible schedules, work from home for some departments. Limited tuition assistance. Employee discounts to other companies (gyms, cell phone providers). 403b.  SHC has a great reputation with patients for excellent care. Very recognizable company.
cons: Pay is very low for similar jobs with other organizations. Employee moral has gone down consistently over the last 6-7 years. IT is a critical department to the organization and is constantly underfunded and possibly mismanaged. Software is outdated and computer systems are slow. The value of the medical benefits is gradually reduced every year. There is currently a lot of uncertainty related to the JCL merger.

review_title: Good Place to get foot in the healthcare door
pros:
supervisors are very approachable
annual raises
management is very open to opinions
they work with your schedule
easy to get time off
work in the office 50% of the time
as long as you show up and do your job, you can move up in the unit
cons:
very unprofessional environment
supervisors tolerate volatility in the workplaces
you'll get paid more to work at in-n-out

review_title: Better than most, but not the best
job_title: Emergency Department RN in Phoenix, AZ
pros: In general, I like my job.  My supervisor is responsive to employees and encourages us the participate in the department.  The pay is competitive (I think).  There are plenty of opportunities for transfer and/or advancement.
cons: After JCL merged with Scottsdale, they have been cleaning house and pretty much firing all the upper management, which is sometimes a good thing, some times not.  Unfortunately, it creates uncertainty with employees, which leads to higher turn over.  My other complaint is the insurance.  I HATE AmeriBen, which is management company for our insurance.  They are constantly trying to scam me into paying for stuff they should cover, so I have to call and tell them how to do their job.  I am honestly looking for another job in part beacuase I am so frustrated with them.  Also, if you live in the west valley, there are limited options for providers.

review_title: Stability + Benefits + no growth opportunities =  unhappy

cons:
Because it is difficult to get terminated you end up working with co workers whom you resent because you do the right thing and they do not.
I have applied for several other opportunities and not had much luck getting further. Manager and Director turn around (5 different direct supervisors in 4 + years).

review_title: Took a turn for the worse
pros: Working from home a few days
cons:
The BI department took a big turn for the worse about a year ago. The management group that took over has run it into the ground and forced all the talent to leave (half the team left in a two month period). If you have any desire to grow your skill set and marketability think twice before accepting here. 

Management has zero skills in this arena. Unfortunately, they think they know everything. We had people with over 100 years combined experience and we never were asked once for our opinion and when we did try and bring something up we just got "the look" then labeled a malcontent.  

There is no innovation here. It is just proprietary vendor tools being used which honestly do not work . Data quality is embarrassing, but all they care about is ticket counts and closing tickets. If you care about your work and are efficient that works against you. You will be overloaded with work and given projects others aren’t able to or don’t want to do. There is a lot of favoritism in this group.

review_title: Stop the insanity! Run the other direction.
pros: Nice co-workers and nice office.
cons: Absolute revolving door. Department of 10 had 12 turnovers in a year. The competent are worked to death the lazy and incomplete are praised and promoted. The systems are arcane. Management has lots meetings and ideas but zero plan or foresight. I wouldn't let these bozos run my lemonade stand let alone care for myself or a loved one with a medical issue!

review_title: Was OK, till consultants took over
pros: Good staff, that worked long hours to accomplish goals. Organization is growing so that might mean job security for some. Good 401K benefits.
cons: Lack of leadership in IT.  CIO is trying to change that with the three AVPS he hired.  But that will take 2 yrs. In the meantime they are losing good emoloyees. Be careful of the team you work for. Some have too much work and tasks, while others have very few. Same goes for managers/directors- some have teams of 5 while others have teams of 30-50. Very unfair balance of work and employees. And consultants in IT. They are running the place. Fundamentally that is poor for business and poor for employees retention. And not to mention putting them over budget each month.

pros: Decent salary, 403B, nice facilities

review_title: Registered Nurse - Progressive Care. Osborn campus
pros: The pay was based on years of experience, which for me was good and more than my previous job. They also pay a weekend differential. The onboarding process was efficient. I liked having a computer in every patient room. The physicians were approachable overall.
cons: Staffing was terribly unsafe and the Senior Manager was unprofessional and punitive. She cut back the support staff such as CNA's and secretaries because they 'weren't clocking out for lunch'. We had high acuity patients (five count), including vents without enough assistance to care for them. Report consisted of a piece of paper faxed to you from the ED. I received  a comatose patient from the ED with a blood sugar of 29 which had not been treated and no doctor wanted to accept the patient to give us orders. This is just one example of why I did not want to continue working there. The management is not supportive at all. I did not feel I could continue to work there.

review_title: I use to really like working here
pros: I love my co-workers . They are the reason I'm still here. Great team for many years ! Close to freeways. Easy to commute.
cons: The issue is upper management has no clue what the people who are keeping them employees to make secessions truly do. I understand you have to budget in business but this isn't a grocery store with food items ! These are people's lives we are responsible for . They don't see patients or there employees as people we have all become just numbers to them.

review_title: Extremely Happy with Benefits, Pay, & Opportunities for Continuing Ed
pros: Fantastic tuition reimbursement, generous PTO, management values continuing education and offers opportunities throughout the year, opportunity for an annual bonus and raises,  relatively low-cost health/dental/vision insurance, and management seems to care about our ideas.  This is a growing organization and I'm genuinely thrilled to be part of it.
cons: We accrue paid sick time too slowly and the time available is often inadequate especially for those who have children, aging parents, chronic health conditions, etc.

pros: Good staff, friendly, hard working coworkers. Staff who is looking out for the best interest of patients.
cons: The Leadership is abysmal. Too much cronyism from the top down. Management spends too much time in meetings looking for solutions to problems when the answer is in the mirror. Lack of respect for staff resulting in very low morale. Inability to get equipment due to attempts to keep budget low only results in poor work. Things have only gone from bad to worse since merging with John C. Lincoln.

review_title: Growing too fast to keep up
pros: Large, multi-hospital system.  In recent years the John C Lincoln Healthcare system and Scottsdale Healthcare systems merged to created this new conglomerate.
cons: This system grew too fast with the merger; dealing with the new size and merge has proven difficult.  RN pay is low, and moral can be low; particularly in the smaller hospitals (Thompson Peak Pkwy).  Additionally, the push to keep cost down can lead to unsafe practices.

pros: Scottsdale Healthcare and John C. Lincoln merged to form Honor Health.  Many changes have taken place and continue to take place.  Together the two Healthcare systems are trying to meet the demands of the changing healthcare market.
cons: Pay salary has been stagnant for many years.  Merit raises despite being a top performer are 1-3%.  Increased committees that take time away from the patient.  Many new positions at the management and executive  level to manage the merger between the two hospital systems.

review_title: Great place to work with an awesome vision!

cons: Nothing in my department nursing wise. A couple of physicians could have a pulse check with their temperaments, but otherwise I have no cons to share.

job_title: Storage Administrator II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Everyone that works there really does want to do the best they can to work together and solve problems and give good and solid recommendations on how to move forward.
cons: Non technical management listens more to vendor sale staff that its own engineers. In the 4 years I was there we had 3 major buys for storage. In all 3 the storage team was unanimous on what we should use. In all 3 management went an entirely different direction and bought hardware from another vendor. In all cases the purchased hardware was more expensive. In one case SEVERAL million dollars more expensive.

pros: Salaries are competitive. Office is nice in Scottsdale.
cons: Management team uses an outdated model. Very top down. The merger was an unpleasant experience especially for JCL employees. All or most of the management jobs went to Scottsdale people. The cultures were very different. JCL was a great place to work prior to the merger but I wouldn't choose to go back and I'm hearing the same thing from other middle managers - both clinical & at the business office.

pros: Used to be a great place to work. Good clinicians.
cons: Terrible management and human resources. Example: a new director was hired and within a couple of months of her hiring (weeks actually) several people had complained bout her lack of knowledge, condescending attitude and extremely poor management style. This included two employees she brought with her from a prior job. No one in the department had anything good to say about her in a meeting with human resources and instead of replacing her they gave her two more hospitals and more staff to supervise! Makes no sense but is indicative of the overall lack of concern over employees and inexperienced, unqualified leadership.

pros: HonorHealth focuses on patient care as their top priority. This hospital network provides the proper resources for employees to successfully and professionally perform their jobs in a safe & patient-focused environment. As a PRN employee, they are flexible with scheduling and offer many hours to work with a variety of shifts.
cons: HonorHealth is a Level 1 Trauma Center and at times can be extremely high-stress. Certain trauma patients that come into this hospital can be difficult to deal with emotionally and physically. At times this can be overwhelming, but strict protocols are set in order to provide life-saving procedures and examinations.

review_title: Layoffs, toxic work environment, ineffective management, very political
pros: At some point HonorHealth was a good place to work.  Pay and benefits are average at best for any positions outside of physical application of healthcare.
cons:
The following is my opinion and events listed are as I remember them.  In my opinion any positions outside of nursing, physicians and their support staff are viewed as liabilities....not assets to this organization.  In fact, the exact description from one of the top officers of the organization referring to a support employee at corporate was "a necessary evil."  If you want to work at an organization that views you as a "necessary evil" then you have come to the right place.  I was disgusted when I heard this and knew my tenure here would be as short as I could manage.  The really for me summarized how they treat their employees.  If you want to give 5, 10, 15, 20 years to an organization only for them to lay you off as a reward, again, you have come to the right place.  

Go to their headquarters and walk around the first level of the covered parking structure and you'll see why people can't afford healthcare anymore.   It's basically like an episode of MTV Cribs.   Porsche, Mercedes, BMW......at a "nonprofit."  There's very little that's not-for-profit here other than their company structure.  Speaking of the executives, it seems to be a pattern here that they routinely miscalculate or go over budget causing a company-wide panic to save money every 3-5 years.  When they do, look out, they're chopping heads.  Not in the areas they really need to, but in positions that have absolute minuscule impacts on the overall costs of the organization.   If you're so poor at consistently managing budgets, why are you still executives?  Any for profit publicly traded organization would have gutted this executive team and board a long time ago.

This is definitely one of those places where they seem to put who you're friends with before results and performance.  Many times it would be a joke around the office about who was and wasn't being promoted.  Knowing and befriending the right people goes a LONG way here....especially in the upper tiers.   You can chronically under-perform for years and you'll keep getting raises until basically you jump out of the plane with your golden parachute.

The toxicity of some of the teams here is truly world class.  Backstabbing, threatening, and just overall management 101 - how not to do things.  I was privy one of the most disgusting unprofessional terminations of my professional career here.

Extremely silo'd you definitely don't want to get on the bad side of certain groups of the "in crowd" regardless if your sole intention is to help the organization.

pros: Sometimes you can leave early if it's not busy.  Decent coworkers.  That's about all I can say about the lab here.  Cheap benefits options.  Wellness discounts.
cons: Very poor leadership, poor management, the people in charge don't care about employee satisfaction or employee engagement.  The powers that be do whatever they want with no regard for how it effects the staff.  Morale is really low every single day and night, no one wants to be there, everyone is looking for jobs at different facilities, pay has been decreased since the merger with Scottsdale.  New employees are making way less than people who were hired just a year ago before the merger for doing the same exact job.  Management team plays favorites among employees, some people can come in whenever they feel like it, others can't.  Some people can call out once a week or once a pay period and it's okay, but others catch hell for calling out once a year.  PTO accrual rate is poor.  Combined vacation and sick time is a joke when the accrual rate is so bad.  They don't do pay raises based on performance so there is no incentive to do well or go above and beyond.  Since merging with Scottsdale, this non-profit facility now operates like a for-profit facility.  Their integrity is gone, along with most of their staff.  Benefits are horrendous.  I've had to pay out of pocket for basic procedures that almost all other insurances cover in full.

pros: Great benefits, excellent staff. My director is caring and understands the needs of the department.  My staff share in the workload, always willing to help one another to get work done or adjust schedule.
cons: Too top-heavy from AVP level and up. It's discouraging that we continue to higher executive positions when departments are being reorganized and continues throughout the organization.

pros: Many Individuals who work for this company have for an expended period of time. Having employees stay after 10+years says a lot about a company. I work with great, well trained staff members and the physicians are approachable and willing to teach.
cons: As a long time employee, I don't have much in the way of negative comments towards this company. However, if we could find a way to train more staff members on different types of critical patients, critical procedures, staffing in the ICUs may be less troublesome.

pros: The older nurses really care about the hospital and patients, the benefits are adequate and the PTO is good.
cons: The recent merger between SHC and JCL has led to high management bringing in outside consultants that seem bent on destroying the system. When I started 5 years previous there were no travelers or registry staff, when I left half of some floors were travelers. I have nothing against travel nurses but all the young talent to replace the retiring nurses were driven out.

pros:
- Great tuition reimbursement benefits, however, you are now required to remain with the company in PT or FT status for two years after the last disbursement or have to pay back a portion of the monies. It basically ensures a job after graduation. 
- Plenty of work, the network is very busy.
- PTO accrues quickly. 
- There are opportunities for growth if you are a hard worker and the director likes you. However, units can be cliquey.
cons:
- Colleagues are hit or miss in attitude and willingness to work as a team. 
- EVS/housekeeping staff makes a higher hourly wage than PCTs. 
- PCTs with 'more skills' (PCT II) are hired onto floors where they do not utilize those additional skills (EKGs, blood draws, etc), yet they are being paid more than then a PCT I to do the same job. 
-Staff loses a lot of time in their shift due to disorganization and lack of support and resources. 
-Poor layouts in the patient room layouts are frustrating, especially in the higher acuity areas. A simple task can become incredibly time-consuming and before you know it you're hours behind. 
- Cleanliness leaves a lot to be desired. Equipment is old and not well taken care of by the staff. Public areas are sloppy. 
-Hospital kitchen is disgusting, very poor food handling. Poorly trained staff, minimal hand washing, and bad attitudes. Kitchen management is just coasting through their day without enforcing proper food handling, therefore creating a public health risk. Try to use food for a long as possible. It is a disservice to our patients, visitors, and staff.

job_title: Patient Care Tech II in Phoenix, AZ

pros: Benefits. Coworkers. Earn PTO quickly. Hours worked well with my hectic schedule.

pros: Paid better than most places.

pros: Great people, great co-workers all very mission driven. John C. Lincoln has been a pillar in the community for decades.

review_title: Honor Health always upholds its culture of excellence, honesty and caring.
job_title: RN Nurse Supervisor in Scottsdale, AZ

pros: Great benefits. Competitive salary. Right off of 101 and I-17.

Administrators highly adversarial to employees exercising rights such as ADA and FMLA.   Functioning off of very old, outdated job descriptions.    Female leadership  is extraordinarily adversarial toward other female leadership.  Leadership needs a complete overhaul in training and potential liabilities to the company.

pros: Great clinical staff, administrative staff, and clerical staff.

review_title: It is what you make of it...

cons: Unprofessional team management. Unrealistic expectations of staff. Lots of turnover in the last few years. Depending on where you work it can be a hostile work.environment.

review_title: Better than most, but could use minor improvements

cons: Stressful environment, hospital coffee shops aren't 24 hours, can take a really long time to get approved for vacations depending on department.  Also, depending on department, employees may be made to feel expendable

pros: Newer equipment, basic training.  Great if you are excellent at corporate politics. Put forth good values.  Good benefits (health insurance) but that's about it.

review_title: The Changing Face of Health Care, Oy!

job_title: K9 Security Officer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pay is above average for security field. There is also a decent shift differential for evening and night shift workers.
cons: Supervisors & security management could care less about their subordinates well being. Any concerns brought forward are quickly dismissed, and if you try to go outside of your department (HR) you're doomed!

pros: Nice facility. Great bedside staff nurses. Good pay. Good benefits. Magnet facility. Safe pt care. Meets nursing metrics. Decent ratios at the moment (set to be increased starting Jan 2016). Working hard to change computer softwares to improve staff and pt satisfaction. Interested and working on pt community outreach facilities and programs. No mandated scrub colors for nursing staff.
cons: Terrible communication from administration down to bedside staff. Most decisions come from high instead of bedside RNs having autonomy, which has resulted in recent very low staff engagement survey results (only 12% staff are engaged at the Osborn campus). Hire management positions only based on education credentials instead of best personality combined with education for the position. Since merger with JCL- administration only seems concerned about the bottom dollar. Feels like big corporate mentality now. Administration does not allow any negative comments to be spoken without retaliation. Directors are being pushed out and eliminated so they can consolidate one Director for an entire floor instead of one per unit/specialty. All this accomplishes is directors who are spread way too thin and communication gets even worse for the bedside staff. No fair scoring system for yearly evaluations and merit. It's vey subjective to who is writing it. HR runs the place- they trump most decisions made by management related to staff discipline and such. Recruitment to hire new staff takes like two or more months to get someone in (that's not including hands on training). Terrible supply shortages due to budget cuts.

pros: I was able to network well through this job however the pay is absolute garbage. If you're trying to get experience for school and don't need much money this is your job
cons: The pay is garbage. I was given the run around about getting a raise for 5 months and still have yet to receive it after being named the preceptor at the same time the raise was mentioned.

pros: Amazing people work here; high quality talent and welcoming personalities. Everyone works together to meet needs and exceeds most expectations.
